natural problem: How many 3-digit numbers have a first digit which is triple the final digit?
natural solution: There are only three possibilities for the first digit: \[ \begin{array}{|c|c|}\hline \text{First digit} & \text{Last digit} \\ \hline 3 & 1 \\ \hline 6 & 2 \\ \hline 9 & 3 \\ \hline \end{array} \] The middle digit can be any of the $10$ digits.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 100 \<and> n < 1000 \<and> fst_digit n = 3 * last_digit n"
shows  "card {n. n \<ge> 100 \<and> n < 1000 \<and> fst_digit n = 3 * last_digit n} = 30"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many 3-digit numbers have a first digit which is triple the final digit? The final Answer is 30
 ### Proof
 There are only three possibilities for the first digit: \[ \begin{array}{|c|c|}\hline \text{First digit} & \text{Last digit} \\ \hline 3 & 1 \\ \hline 6 & 2 \\ \hline 9 & 3 \\ \hline \end{array} \] The middle digit can be any of the $10$ digits.
 The answer is $3\times 10=\boxed{30}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 100 \<and> n < 1000 \<and> fst_digit n = 3 * last_digit n"
shows  "card {n. n \<ge> 100 \<and> n < 1000 \<and> fst_digit n = 3 * last_digit n} = 30"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: How many three-digit numbers have the property that their first digit is three times their last digit? The final answer is 30.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "100 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 999"
and h1 : "n div 100 = 3 * (n mod 10)"
shows  "card {n. 100 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 999 \<and> n div 100 = 3 * (n mod 10)} = 30"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many 3-digit numbers have a first digit which is triple the final digit? The final Answer is 30
 ### Proof
 There are only three possibilities for the first digit: \[ \begin{array}{|c|c|}\hline \text{First digit} & \text{Last digit} \\ \hline 3 & 1 \\ \hline 6 & 2 \\ \hline 9 & 3 \\ \hline \end{array} \] The middle digit can be any of the $10$ digits.
 The answer is $3\times 10=\boxed{30}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "100 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 999"
and h1 : "n div 100 = 3 * (n mod 10)"
shows  "card {n. 100 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 999 \<and> n div 100 = 3 * (n mod 10)} = 30"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: How many three-digit numbers have the property that the hundreds digit is three times the units digit? The final answer is 30.

a_2.informal problem: How many three-digit numbers have the property that the digit in the hundreds place is three times the digit in the units (ones) place? The final answer is 30.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes three_digit_numbers :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "three_digit_numbers = {n. 100 \<le> n \<and> n < 1000}"
and h1 : "triple_final_digit_numbers = {n \<in> three_digit_numbers. n div 100 = 3 * (n mod 10)}"
shows  "card triple_final_digit_numbers = 30"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many 3-digit numbers have a first digit which is triple the final digit? The final Answer is 30
 ### Proof
 There are only three possibilities for the first digit: \[ \begin{array}{|c|c|}\hline \text{First digit} & \text{Last digit} \\ \hline 3 & 1 \\ \hline 6 & 2 \\ \hline 9 & 3 \\ \hline \end{array} \] The middle digit can be any of the $10$ digits.
 The answer is $3\times 10=\boxed{30}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes three_digit_numbers :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "three_digit_numbers = {n. 100 \<le> n \<and> n < 1000}"
and h1 : "triple_final_digit_numbers = {n \<in> three_digit_numbers. n div 100 = 3 * (n mod 10)}"
shows  "card triple_final_digit_numbers = 30"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: How many three-digit numbers have the property that their first digit is three times their last digit? The final answer is 30.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "(nat \<Rightarrow> nat) \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "f = (\<lambda>g. g (\<lambda>n. 100 * (3 * n) + 10 * n + n))"
and h1 : "g \<in> {1..9}"
and h2 : "g n = card {m. m = f g \<and> m \<in> {100..999}}"
shows  "sum g {1..9} = 30"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many 3-digit numbers have a first digit which is triple the final digit? The final Answer is 30
 ### Proof
 There are only three possibilities for the first digit: \[ \begin{array}{|c|c|}\hline \text{First digit} & \text{Last digit} \\ \hline 3 & 1 \\ \hline 6 & 2 \\ \hline 9 & 3 \\ \hline \end{array} \] The middle digit can be any of the $10$ digits.
 The answer is $3\times 10=\boxed{30}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "(nat \<Rightarrow> nat) \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "f = (\<lambda>g. g (\<lambda>n. 100 * (3 * n) + 10 * n + n))"
and h1 : "g \<in> {1..9}"
and h2 : "g n = card {m. m = f g \<and> m \<in> {100..999}}"
shows  "sum g {1..9} = 30"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Let $f(g) = g(100(3n) + 10n + n)$ for a function $g$ and $g(n)$ be the number of times $f(g)$ appears in the range of 100 to 999, for $g$ in the range of 1 to 9. Find the sum of $g(n)$ for all values of $g$ from 1 to 9. The final answer is 30.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 100 \<and> n \<le> 999 \<and> f n = 3 * (n mod 10) \<longrightarrow> n div 100 = 3 * (n mod 10)"
shows  "card {n. n \<ge> 100 \<and> n \<le> 999 \<and> n div 100 = 3 * (n mod 10)} = 30"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many 3-digit numbers have a first digit which is triple the final digit? The final Answer is 30
 ### Proof
 There are only three possibilities for the first digit: \[ \begin{array}{|c|c|}\hline \text{First digit} & \text{Last digit} \\ \hline 3 & 1 \\ \hline 6 & 2 \\ \hline 9 & 3 \\ \hline \end{array} \] The middle digit can be any of the $10$ digits.
 The answer is $3\times 10=\boxed{30}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 100 \<and> n \<le> 999 \<and> f n = 3 * (n mod 10) \<longrightarrow> n div 100 = 3 * (n mod 10)"
shows  "card {n. n \<ge> 100 \<and> n \<le> 999 \<and> n div 100 = 3 * (n mod 10)} = 30"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: How many three-digit numbers have the property that the first digit (hundreds place) is equal to three times the last digit (ones place)? The final answer is 30.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> a b. f a b = a * 100 + b * 10 + b * 3"
and h1 : "GREATEST n. (\<exists> a b. a < 10 \<and> b < 10 \<and> a * 100 + b * 10 + b * 3 = n) = 999"
shows  "card {n. \<exists> a b. a < 10 \<and> b < 10 \<and> f a b = n} = 30"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many 3-digit numbers have a first digit which is triple the final digit? The final Answer is 30
 ### Proof
 There are only three possibilities for the first digit: \[ \begin{array}{|c|c|}\hline \text{First digit} & \text{Last digit} \\ \hline 3 & 1 \\ \hline 6 & 2 \\ \hline 9 & 3 \\ \hline \end{array} \] The middle digit can be any of the $10$ digits.
 The answer is $3\times 10=\boxed{30}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> a b. f a b = a * 100 + b * 10 + b * 3"
and h1 : "GREATEST n. (\<exists> a b. a < 10 \<and> b < 10 \<and> a * 100 + b * 10 + b * 3 = n) = 999"
shows  "card {n. \<exists> a b. a < 10 \<and> b < 10 \<and> f a b = n} = 30"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Consider a function $f(a, b) = a * 100 + b * 10 + b * 3$ for all natural numbers $a$ and $b$. Determine the number of unique values for $f(a, b)$ when $a$ and $b$ are both less than 10 and the greatest such value is 999. The final answer is 30.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes count :: nat and numbers :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "numbers = {n. 100 \<le> n \<and> n < 1000 \<and> (\<exists>x y. n = 100 * x + 10 * y + x div 3)}"
and h1 : "count = card numbers"
shows  "count = 30"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many 3-digit numbers have a first digit which is triple the final digit? The final Answer is 30
 ### Proof
 There are only three possibilities for the first digit: \[ \begin{array}{|c|c|}\hline \text{First digit} & \text{Last digit} \\ \hline 3 & 1 \\ \hline 6 & 2 \\ \hline 9 & 3 \\ \hline \end{array} \] The middle digit can be any of the $10$ digits.
 The answer is $3\times 10=\boxed{30}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes count :: nat and numbers :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "numbers = {n. 100 \<le> n \<and> n < 1000 \<and> (\<exists>x y. n = 100 * x + 10 * y + x div 3)}"
and h1 : "count = card numbers"
shows  "count = 30"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: How many numbers between 100 and 1000 satisfy the condition that the number can be represented in the form $100x + 10y + \frac{x}{3}$, where $x$ and $y$ are integers? The final answer is 30.
